unnormalised: EdTech sector sees massive growth in Tier 2 and Tier 3 cities, says report. A recent study by EduAnalytics shows a 60% increase in online learning adoption in cities like Lucknow and Jaipur compared to last year.
normalised: E-d-Tech sector sees massive growth in Tier two and Tier three cities, says report. A recent study by EduAnalytics shows a sixty percent increase in online learning adoption in cities like Lucknow and Jaipur compared to last year.

unnormalised: The report, released on 10/26/2024, attributes this surge to increased internet penetration and affordability of online courses. "Parents in smaller towns are now more willing to invest in online education for their children, especially after seeing the impact of COVID-19," said Dr. Meera Sharma, lead author of the study and professor at IIM Bangalore.
normalised: The report, released on twenty sixth october two thousand and twenty four, attributes this surge to increased internet penetration and affordability of online courses. "Parents in smaller towns are now more willing to invest in online education for their children, especially after seeing the impact of C-O-V-I-D-nineteen," said Dr. Meera Sharma, lead author of the study and professor at I-I-M Bangalore.

unnormalised: The data indicates that K-12 segment (Kindergarten to Class 12) is the biggest driver, with platforms like Byju's and Vedantu reporting a 75% growth in their user base from these regions. Subjects like Maths and Science are particularly popular, with students using online platforms to supplement their school curriculum.

Subjects like Maths and Science are particularly popular, with students using online platforms to supplement their school curriculum.

unnormalised: "We've seen a significant rise in demand for our coding courses in cities like Indore and Patna," said a spokesperson from WhiteHat Jr. "Students are eager to learn new skills that will give them an edge in the future."

unnormalised: The report also highlights the growing popularity of online test preparation platforms for competitive exams like JEE and NEET. Many students are opting for online coaching instead of traditional coaching centers, citing convenience and cost-effectiveness. Packages often cost between Rs. 10000 and Rs. 50000 annually, significantly less than brick-and-mortar institutes.

Packages often cost between rupees ten thousand and rupees fifty thousand annually, significantly less than brick-and-mortar institutes.

unnormalised: Challenges remain, however. Digital literacy and reliable internet access are still major hurdles in some areas. The study recommends increased government investment in infrastructure and digital literacy programs to further boost online learning adoption.

unnormalised: Furthermore, a separate survey by the National Education Board (NEB) revealed that only 40% of govt. schools have adequate access to digital learning resources. Experts emphasize the need for equitable access to quality online education for all students, regardless of their socioeconomic background. Platforms like Khan Academy are offering free educational content to bridge this gap.

unnormalised: The EduAnalytics report concludes that the EdTech sector has the potential to revolutionize education in India, but requires a collaborative effort from the government, private companies, and educational institutions to ensure its sustainable and inclusive growth. The next phase of growth is expected to be driven by vernacular content and personalized learning experiences, with platforms focusing on regional languages like Hindi and Tamil. Look for expansion in regional markets in the next 6-12 months.
